description.narrative: The main goal of this development intervention was to educate the young and adult population in Ukraine towards a more rational use of energy, water and responsible garbage management, and in this way, promote sustainable development. As the result of intervention, 18 out of 25 regions total in Ukraine have demonstration projects and courses for sustainable education. Many trainings, presentations, conferences and teacher orientations have been held to expand the client base for the undertaking. The project has engaged 184 thousand families and reached about a thousand schools. Through the program, an action oriented school subject for sustainable development was developed (Lessons for Sustainable Development), which thereafter was imposed in all classes from kindergarten to 9th grade. This process included the development of textbooks, and teachers guides, that introduced a new way of pedagogic work, aiming for a more inclusive and democratic classroom where the pupils learn and interact by monitoring their own and their family’s lifestyle. During this process, the children explore how they themselves, their friends and families can save environmental and economic resources by changing their behavior regarding waste, water and energy management. While engaging in the program, some teachers witness how they changed both in their teaching qualities in the classroom and personal lifestyle regarding sustainability. Parents notice how their children grow in and spread their new environmental awareness by enforcing waste recycling, and collecting batteries at home. As result of the program some schools developed a whole school approach for sustainable development and started to compete for the award for the most sustainable school. The sustainable development lessons involved 3000 households. In total 1000 schools, 450 kindergartens, 183544 families, 180544 students and preschool children, 5520 teachers and educators participated in the project. 97500 student books and teachers guides were produced. As a result, the families of students studying lessons for sustainable development decreased their water usage by 11%, electricity by 14% and waste by 16%. In addition to the school lessons for sustainable development an EcoTeam program for 2,000 families and households was carried out during 2014 and 2015 in the city of Ivano-Frankivsk. After the 8-week EcoTeam program, its participants decreased water usage by 18%, electricity by 17% and waste by 27,5%. The lessons for sustainable development highlighted the rational use of energy, water and responsible garbage management. In Grades 1-4 the children worked with the project My Happy Planet which aimed to give understanding of planetary as well as local challenges. For grades 5-7 extracurricular lessons were developed. The 5th graders learned for example by participating in a role play called “A journey to planet Tellus”. Grades 8-9 had a special course with lessons for sustainable development that took place once a week where they researched the impact of their own lifestyles ecological footprint by for example weighing garbage. For each grade a teacher toolkit with text books for students and manual for teachers was developed. The innovative education model included empowerment pedagogy, critical thinking, interactive and online learning. Among the students of grade 5-9 who took part in the sustainable development course 82% got aware aware of specific sustainable behaviors, while only 37% of the students who hadnät taken this course had some sustainable development behavioral patterns. Students who had taken the sustainable development course were also to a scientifically higher degree ready to take sustainability action. 82% of students surveyed enjoyed their Lessons for sustainable development. 81% of parents noticed a greater attention to use of water and electricity. The project lasted from 2010 to 2016 and had 25 partner organizations including international NGOs from several countries such as Sweden, Hungary,Norway and Vietnam. The media coverage of the program was good including 60+ TV-spots, 10+ radio programs covering the program and 50+ original publications. The project contributed to activities and festivals such as Gogol Fest 2015 in Kyiv.
